bioghist.p: Robert Pierre Johnson (1914-1974) was a Presbyterian minister who in 1967 was elected Executive Presbyter of New York City. He received his B.D. from Union Theological Seminary in 1940 and was ordained in the same year. He served pastorates in Pennsylvania and Washington D.C. and served as a field representative of Negro Work in the North and West for the Interboard Commission of New York and as Assistant Secretary in the Department of City and Industrial Work. In 1971, the United Presbyterian Church's Council on Church and Race (COCAR) authorized the dispersal of $10,000 to the Marin County Black Defense Fund in support of Angela Davis, who was charged with murder and kidnapping in connection a Black Panther prison escape. COCAR's action was criticized by some members of the church, and as a result, 20 black Presbyterians, Robert Pierre Johnson among them, joined together to reimburse the Emergency Legal Aid Fund.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Robert Pierre Johnson. Materials include: correspondence (1954-1967) with fellow ministers, parishioners, and members of various church-related organizations; sermons and notes for sermons; a travel diary from a trip Johnson took to Europe in 1963; a small amount of material relating to the Black Presbyterians United; a copy of Johnson's thesis The Economic Doctrines of John Calvin (1940); and Johnson's files on the Presbyterian Church's donation to Angela Davis's defense, the Church's response to the Black Manifesto, the Black Panthers, and black involvement in the Church. These files include articles, correspondence, press releases, and policy statements. The collection also includes a 1916 bulletin from the Fifteenth Street Presbyterian Church in Washington D.C.
